framework_intro.para: Here is a framework to help you use sources effectively. This model is very flexible, but gives you advice on the right ways to use sources. There are spaces for you to add your own text, if you wish to practise.

commentary.para: Writers use sources for many different reasons, including:
- proving that facts are true;
- explaining what is known about a topic;
- giving credit for ideas, discoveries, etc.;
- showing that experts agree or disagree;
- convincing readers that the writer is knowledgeable.

step.label: Why is it important to use sources?

commentary.para: Appropriate references to sources make your writing stronger, but only if readers understand how sources have been used.
Show your reader:
- which ideas come from sources;
- which sources you have used;
- whether you have used the source's language.

step.label: How to signal an idea is from a source

commentary.para: The most common way to show that an idea, a fact, etc. comes from a source is to give a reference (also called a citation). If you do not give a reference, readers will assume that the idea is yours.
Think about:
- positioning references carefully to show what material they cover;
- reporting ideas carefully, so that they are not changed or distorted.

step.label: Where do you signal your sources?

commentary.para: Sources are identified in two places:
- the reference in the body of the text;
- a reference list (also called a works cited list) at the end.

Secondary citation is when writers refer to sources they have seen mentioned but have not read. Try to avoid secondary citation by going to the original source, but if that is not possible, then signal a secondary citation clearly.
You can see an example of a secondary citation in the model text by clicking ‘Look at Paragraph 2’.

step.label: Look at the model text and main source

commentary.para: Students on a sociolinguistics module were asked to write a short reflection on a variety of English they found personally important.
This is the main source material they used:
From Smith (2012), chapter four: Australian English

Australian English (AusE) presents an interesting case for the sociolinguistic observer. Its description usually takes British English as a reference variety, and many similarities exist. Indeed, what has been termed ‘cultivated’ AusE is extremely close to RP (Mitchell & Delbridge, 1965). Phonologically, AusE is non-rhotic, and its long vowels…

However, it would be wrong to disregard the many features which make this variety unique. One of the most typical examples is the pervasive Australian hypocorisms: shortened word forms such as ‘barbie’ (barbecue), ‘brekky’ (breakfast) and ‘addy’ (address). Other lexical features of note include…

Australia is commonly perceived around the world as a vibrant, dynamic young country. It is possible that the unique variety of English which has emerged there—an exciting, twenty-first century mélange of the European and the antipodal, the old and the new world—is in part responsible for that view.
The writer has a point to make, so it is easier to use sources to support that point.
The reference shows who originated this term.
TIP: The author-date system is used in the social sciences.
The writer paraphrases the source.
The writer knows that this is common knowledge, so no reference is needed.
The position of the reference shows that the first half of the sentence comes from the source, but not the second.
This writer uses several sources and relates them to each other. Here, Smith's general statement is limited by Mitchell and Delbridge.
Secondary citation
‘Enthusiastically’ gives the writer's interpretation of Smith; the enthusiastic wording may be why the writer felt a quotation was needed.
Quotation marks show where the quotation begins and ends. An ellipsis (…) shows omitted words.
By citing a range of sources, the writer gives a more thorough view of the topic.
Remember that the citations in your text must be listed in the References list at the end.
Look at the Writing Mode for more information on citing sources.

step.label: A less successful use of sources

commentary.para: This text on the same topic was written by another student, who has used sources less successfully.
A less clear focus leads this writer into the trap of simply listing facts from sources, rather than using them for a purpose.
Copying with changes is not a good paraphrase.
It is unclear from the position of the reference that this and the preceding sentence both come from Smith.

checklist.point: Academic writing is not only about the writer's own ideas; it builds on what is already known about a topic, and so writers usually have to find and read various sources of information and include part of what they learned from their sources in their texts. Learning the right ways to use sources is important.
Think about how and why you will use sources.
Think about how you will signal your sources.

Have I used sources in my work?
Have I shown which ideas come from sources?

Have I used quotation marks, ellipsis and square brackets when necessary?
Have I referred to my sources in the correct format?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Writing from Sources
paragraph.desc: Correct and effective ways to use sources

paragraph.name: Paragraph 1
paragraph.desc: Make a point and use sources to support it.

content.para: An important variety of English for me is Australian English (henceforth AusE), for three reasons. First, Australia is the nearest inner circle English-speaking country(Kachru, 1985) to my own, and as a result has political and economic importance for us.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 2
paragraph.desc: Continue to develop points using sources to support them.

content.para: The second is thatAusE resembles British English in many respects (Smith, 2012),probably because it is a former British colony.While it is true that these similarities are greater in some varieties of AusE than others (Mitchell & Delbridge, 1965, cited in Smith, 2012), their existence makes AusE easier for those of us who learned British English at school.

paragraph.name: Paragraph 3
paragraph.desc: Continue to develop points and to support them from sources.
paragraph.tip: TIP: You may need further paragraphs. Use as many paragraphs as are appropriate.

content.para: Finally, AusE is distinctive in several ways. One is the use of shortened forms like ‘barbie’ for barbecue and ‘arvo’ for afternoon(Smith, 2012). Indeed,Simpson, 2001, identifies 346 Australian hypocorisms for place names alone. There are also a number of Aboriginal terms, such as ‘kookaburra’ and ‘wallaby’(Melchers & Shaw, 2011). This combination of ‘borrowed’ and ‘native’ features creates an interesting effect, or,as Smith enthusiastically puts it,‘an exciting, twenty-first century mélange of … the old and new world’ (2001, p. 45). My shared fascination for this mixture helps explain my liking for this variety of English.

paragraph.name: References
paragraph.desc: A list of the references you have used in your text
paragraph.tip: TIP: Remember to record bibliographic data (title, author, publisher and page numbers) for every source you read during your preparation. </br>TIP: In your bibliography, include all the works mentioned in your writing. Do not include references to works that you do not mention.

para.extra_info: I have chosen to write about Australian English, which is very similar to British English, especially in its phonology and ...
para.p: But some parts of Australian English are different, too, including some words likethe pervasive Australian hypocorisms, which are shortened word forms.Smith (2012) gives examples such as ‘barbie’ (barbecue), ‘brekky’ (breakfast) and ‘addy’ (address).
So, because of these similarities and differences, Australian English is an important variety.
